specJson.name: brightics.function.recommendation$als_recommend
specJson.label: ALS Recommend
specJson.description:
Matrix factorization is a class of collaborative filtering algorithms used in recommender systems. Matrix factorization algorithms work by decomposing the user-item iteraction matrix into the product of two lower dimensionality rectangular matrices. One matrix is a user latent vector where rows represent users and columns are latent factors. The other matrix is a item latent vector where rows are latent factors and columns represent items. And Rating of item _i_ given by user _u_ can be expressed as a dot product of the user latent vector and the item latent vector.

ALS(Alternating Least Squares) is also a matrix factorization algorithm and it runs itself in a parallel fashion. The idea behind ALS is to minimize two loss funcitions alternatively. It first holds user matrix fixed and runs gradient descent with item matrix. Then it holds item matrix fixed and runs gradient descent with user matrix. ALS is doing a pretty good job at solving scalability and sparseness of the ratings data, and it's simple and scales well to very large datasets.

Reference:
+ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_factorization_(recommender_systems)>
+ <http://stanford.edu/~rezab/classes/cme323/S15/notes/lec14.pdf>
+ <https://towardsdatascience.com/prototyping-a-recommender-system-step-by-step-part-2-alternating-least-square-als-matrix-4a76c58714a1>

params.label: Number of recommendations
params.description: Number of recommendations in the top N list.

params.label: Filter already liked items
params.description:
Whether to filter already liked items. If `True`, it does not recommend the items that user already rated.
   - Available Options : `True`, `False`

params.label: Target Users
params.description: Target users to recommend top N items. Default is all users found in data.

params.label: Implicit Preference
params.description:
Whether to use the explicit feedback ALS variant or one adapted for implicit feedback data.
   - Available Options : `True`, `False`

params.label: Seed
params.description: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results.

params.label: Rank
params.description: Number of latent factors to use in the model.

params.label: Workers
params.description: Number of workers. Recommended only if target is all.

specJson.summary: This function recommends Top-N items for users by using the ALS(alternating least squares) algorithm based recommender model.

md:
# ALS Recommend This function recommends Top-N items for users by using the ALS(alternating least squares) algorithm based recommender model. ## Description Matrix factorization is a class of collaborative filtering algorithms used in recommender systems. Matrix factorization algorithms work by decomposing the user-item iteraction matrix into the product of two lower dimensionality rectangular matrices. One matrix is a user latent vector where rows represent users and columns are latent factors. The other matrix is a item latent vector where rows are latent factors and columns represent items. And Rating of item _i_ given by user _u_ can be expressed as a dot product of the user latent vector and the item latent vector. ALS(Alternating Least Squares) is also a matrix factorization algorithm and it runs itself in a parallel fashion. The idea behind ALS is to minimize two loss funcitions alternatively. It first holds user matrix fixed and runs gradient descent with item matrix. Then it holds item matrix fixed and runs gradient descent with user matrix. ALS is doing a pretty good job at solving scalability and sparseness of the ratings data, and it's simple and scales well to very large datasets. Reference + + + ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data in a Table. It must contain `User Column`, `Item Column` and `Rating Column` used in model training. #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (Table) Recommendations of Top-N items for each users with the predicted ratings. #### PARAMETER 1. **User Column***: User column name. 2. **Item Column***: Item column name. 3. **Rating Column***: Rating column names. 4. **Number of recommendations**: Number of recommendations in the top N list. 5. **Filter already liked items**: Whether to filter already liked items. If `True`, it does not recommend the items that user already rated. - Available Options : `True`, `False` - 6. **Target Users**: Target users to recommend top N items. Default is all users found in data. 7. **Implicit Preference**: Whether to use the explicit feedback ALS variant or one adapted for implicit feedback data. - Available Options : `True`, `False` 8. **Iterations**: Maximum number of iteration. 9. **Reg Param**: Regularization parameter in ALS. 10. **Seed**: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results. 11. **Rank**: Number of latent factors to use in the model. 12. **Group By**: Columns to group by. 13. **Workers**: Number of workers. Recommended only if target is all. ### Python #### USAGE ``` als_recommend(table, user_col, item_col, rating_col, number=10, filter=True, targets=None, implicit=False, iterations=10, reg_param=0.1, seed=None, rank=10, alpha=1.0, workers=1, group_by=None) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data in a Table. It must contain `user_col`, `item_col` and `rating_col` used in model training. #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (Table) Recommendations of Top-N items for each users with the predicted ratings. #### PARAMETER 1. **user_col***: User column name. * Type: *str* 2. **item_col***: Item column name. * Type: *str* 3. **rating_col***: Rating column names. * Type: *str* 4. **number**: Number of recommendations in the top N list. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 10 (value >= 1) 5. **filter**: Whether to filter already liked items. If `True`, it does not recommend the items that user already rated. * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: true 6. **targets**: Target users to recommend top N items. Default is all users found in data. * Type: *int*, *float*, *str* 7. **implicit**: Whether to use the explicit feedback ALS variant or one adapted for implicit feedback data. * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: false 8. **iterations**: Maximum number of iteration. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 10 (value >= 1) 9. **reg_param**: Regularization parameter in ALS. * Type: *float* * Default / Range: 0.1 (value >= 0) 10. **seed**: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results. * Type: *int* 11. **rank**: Number of latent factors to use in the model. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 10 (value >= 1) 12. **alpha**: The alpha parameter used in computing confidence in implicit ALS. * Type: *float* * Default / Range: 1.0 (value >= 0) 13. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* 14. **workers**: Number of workers. Recommended only if target is all. * Type: *int* ## Example ### VA **[Sample Model]**
In this tutorial workflow, sample_ALSTrain is used to recommend Top-N items by using the ALS(Alternating Least Squares) algorithm based recommender model. By using ALS Recommend function, we can get recommendations of Top-N items for users in the data with predicted ratings. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ++Parameters++ 1. **User Column***: user 2. **Item Column***: item 3. **Rating Column***: rating 4. **Number of recommendations**: 10 5. **Filter already liked items**: True 6. **Target Users**: None 7. **Implicit Preference**: False 8. **Iterations**: 10 9. **Reg Param**: 0.1 10. **Seed**: None 11. **Rank**: None 12. **Group By**: None 13. **Workers**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.recommendation import als_recommend input_table = inputs[0] result = als_recommend(table=input_table, user_col='user', item_col='item', rating_col='rating', number=10, filter=True, targets=None, implicit=False, iterations=10, reg_param=0.1, seed=None, rank=10, alpha=1.0, workers=1, group_by=None) output = result['out_table'] ```
In this python script, sample_ALSTrain is used to recommend Top-N items by using the ALS(Alternating Least Squares) algorithm based recommender model. By using ALS Recommend function, we can get recommendations of Top-N items for users in the data with predicted ratings.
